item.title: WWII veteran gets special birthday honor after party is canceled because of pandemic
item.dc:creator: Terri Vermeulen Keith, City News Service
item.description: Lt. Col. Sam Sachs celebrated his 105th birthday Sunday with a parade of well-wishers in cars, military vehicles and even an appearance from a Los Angeles County sheriff's helicopter.
item.content:encoded: Lt. Col. Sam Sachs celebrated his 105th birthday Sunday with a parade of well-wishers in cars, military vehicles and even an appearance from a Los Angeles County sheriff's helicopter.

media:content.media:description: LAKEWOOD, CA - APRIL 26, 2020 - - Lt. Col. Sam Sachs, a World War II veteran, celebrates his 105th birthday with well wishers at the Mom & Dad's House, an assisted living facility, in Lakewood on April 27, 2020. Lt. Col. Sachs appealed to the public for birthday cards after the coronavirus pandemic forced the cancellation of a big celebration and wound up receiving thousands, including a letter and photo from President Donald Trump. A surprise parade of cars drove by the senior living home where Sachs resides. Over 400 American flags were brought by community members in honor of his birthday. Well-wishers from throughout the United States and the world have sent birthday cards. The farthest birthday card came from South Korea. "Does life get any better than this," said Lt. Col. Sachs. "I lived a life of a dream," he concluded. Lt. Col. Sachs, who was in the 325th Glider Infantry Regiment of the 82nd Airborne Division, was a high school teacher for 35 years in Huntington Park. He raised his family in Cerritos. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County reports 18 new coronavirus deaths, says poor people are three times more likely to die
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 18 additional COVID-19 deaths and 440 new cases of the coronavirus and said that people in lower-income communities are three times more likely to die from COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 18 additional COVID-19 deaths and 440 new cases of the coronavirus and said that people in lower-income communities are three times more likely to die from COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.content:encoded: Orange County health officials announce 124 new cases and two more deaths, for a total of 1,969 confirmed cases and 38 deaths. The county will launch a testing network Tuesday.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 2020: Denise Martinez, of Costa Mesa, kneels down in prayer in front of the closed Huntington Beach pier as she spreads her message of love, not the anarchy that she says some of the stay-at-home protesters want. "I'm out here praying for the city," Martinez said. "And to show an example of Christ, who is love. Our freedom doesn't come from a spirit of anarchy. Right now our main focus is loving each other at any cost. The lord says today that he hears the cries of his people and to trust him. Because love overcomes everything." Beach-goers enjoyed warm summer-like weather amid state and city social distancing regulations to stave off Coronavirus mandated by Gov. Newsom in Huntington Beach, CA, on April 22, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - APRIL 24, 2020 - - Dr. Steven Siegel, 55, a psychiatrist and Chair of the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Studies with the Keck School of Medicine at USC, stands with his dog Philly outside his office where he works at his home in Glendale on April 24, 2020. Dr. Siegel recommends that people maintain a routine to help them deal with mental stress during the stay at home order during the coronavirus pandemic. His routine involves waking at 5 each morning, feeding his dogs, having breakfast, dressing and working in his spare bedroom which he has converted into an office. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

In San Clemente the local council voted to reopen the beach for recreational activity such as walking, running, swimming and surfing, but have also said residents should not bring a blanket and hang out starting Saturday morning at 6am. The city is attempting to limit access to local residents by keeping parking lots closed, and other Orange county officials have urged out-of-town residents not to visit the beaches and parks that remain open. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus threatens a South L.A. clinic that's long been a lifeline for the working poor
item.dc:creator: Esmeralda Bermudez
item.description: Due to Coronavirus, many patients have stopped going to community clinics, putting funding at risk
item.content:encoded: Due to Coronavirus, many patients have stopped going to community clinics, putting funding at risk

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 08: During the coroniavirus pandemic a woman carries an infant out of entrance to South Central Family Health Center (SCFHC) as people wait to get speak with the medical assistant at the entrance on Wednesday, April 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. For decades, the South Central Family Health Center has been a refuge for low-income families most at risk. They rely on the clinic for medical help; also for help with homeless services, food coupons and emotional support for domestic violence. In recent weeks, so many patients have stopped attending the clinic due to Coronavirus fears, it's put the clinics funding at risk. Officials have furloughed employees, slashed services and put major projects on hold. They said worry that after the pandemic ends, the clinic may not be able to stay open or will only offer a fraction of the critical services it's known for. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mosques raise a big part of their budget during Ramadan. Under coronavirus quarantine, key funding is at risk
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: During Ramadan, mosques around the country are able to raise as much as 30% of their annual revenue through charity from congregants. But as mosques shut their doors under coronavirus quarantine orders, they have been taken a financial hit.
item.content:encoded: During Ramadan, mosques around the country are able to raise as much as 30% of their annual revenue through charity from congregants. But as mosques shut their doors under coronavirus quarantine orders, they have been taken a financial hit.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 22: The Islamic Center of Southern California off of Vermont Avenue on Wednesday, April 22, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Mosques have been put at risk of laying off staff members, including imams, because of losing money during the COVID-19 pandemic. Ramadan is typically a huge fundraising time for mosques, which in some cases can raise as much as 30% of their yearly budget over the holiday. In Southern California, many mosques are feeling the loss and are worried about what losing more money could mean for their futures. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

The phenomenon is associated with a red tide, or an algae bloom, filled with dinoflagellates which react with bioluminescence when jostled by the moving water. During the daytime, due to the pigmentation of the dinoflagellates, the water can turn a deep red, brown, or orange color, giving red tides their name.(Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Why are the dead getting coronavirus stimulus checks?
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: Mary Nakamura was among the first to receive a $1,200 coronavirus stimulus check from the IRS. But she's been dead for more than a year.
item.content:encoded: Mary Nakamura was among the first to receive a $1,200 coronavirus stimulus check from the IRS. But she's been dead for more than a year.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA -- TUESDAY, APRIL 21, 2020: Mason Nakamura holds a photo of himself with his late mother, Mary Nakamura, at his home in Santa Ana, CA, on April 21, 2020. Mary Nakamura received her stimulus payment on April 15. There's just one problem, she's deceased. The 96-year-old died about a year ago but her son Mason Nakamura, who handles her estate account, said his mother received a $1200 check. He wants to give that money back to the IRS, saying it doesn't make sense. Nakamura's mother is likely one of thousands who are deceased but received payments anyway. IRS experts said it's actually lawful for the dead to get stimulus payments and that it's not an error. The priority was put on getting payments out as quickly as possible and weeding out the dead would have likely delayed the process by weeks, if not months. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Still no timetable for reopening California as coronavirus deaths rise

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 2020: Denise Martinez, of Costa Mesa, kneels down in prayer in front of the closed Huntington Beach pier as she spreads her message of love, not the anarchy that she says some of the stay-at-home protesters want. "I'm out here praying for the city," Martinez said. "And to show an example of Christ, who is love. Our freedom doesn't come from a spirit of anarchy. Right now our main focus is loving each other at any cost. The lord says today that he hears the cries of his people and to trust him. Because love overcomes everything." Beach-goers enjoyed warm summer-like weather amid state and city social distancing regulations to stave off Coronavirus mandated by Gov. Newsom in Huntington Beach, CA, on April 22, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA-CA-APRIL 12, 2020: Ashley Amon, 33, and her daughters Alysha, 2, and Alexandria, 4, who are currently homeless, attend a gathering with fellow worshippers in their cars in a parking lot in Santa Ana to worship in an Easter service by Rev. Robert A. Schuller on Sunday, April 12, 2020. Schuller is reviving a practice that launched his father to worldwide acclaim- the drive-in ministry. For the past four years, the younger Schuller has been preaching primarily on social media, providing daily sermons from his "church with no walls." The COVID-19 outbreak - and the loss of in-person fellowship - led him back to his roots. "People need a place to go to worship on Easter, " he said. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: PALM SPRINGS, CALIFORNIA - APRIL 3, 2020: A Palm Springs resident finds the serenity of a closed golf course the perfect place for afternoon reading during the coronavirus pandemic at Tahquitz Creek Golf Resort on April 3, 2020 in Palm Springs. All the golf courses are closed in the desert communities. Declining to give his name, he said he's reading a novel by German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche. Which seems very relevant during these times. Some of Nietzsche's famous quotes are, "To live is to suffer, to survive is to find meaning in the suffering," and "That which does not kill us makes us stronger." Also, "Without music, life would be a mistake."
media:content.media:credit: Gina Ferazzi/Gina Ferazzi/Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times
